#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Prune Ferns
#Text=Ferns are relatively easy to prune .
#Text=You can prune them in early spring before the new growth begins , or even when the new growth comes in .
#Text=If you want to create a shape , you can trim around the edges of the plant .
#Text=When growing ferns indoors , just be sure to cut off dead or dried fronds when they appear .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Pruning Ferns Outdoors
#Text=Check the pruning information for your specific plant .
#Text=Some ferns , such as the Giant Chain Fern , do not do well with spring pruning .
#Text=It 's best to let the old foliage die out by itself in mid-summer .
#Text=If you do n't , you can cause damage to the plant .
#Text=Once the fronds die , you can cut them out .
#Text=Cut back the old foliage early in the spring to make pruning easier .
#Text=It 's easiest to cut back the fern in the spring before the new leaves emerge .
#Text=You should be able to see the tightly rolled fiddleheads , also known as crosiers , in a crown on the plant .
#Text=Cut the foliage just above the crown with a sharp pair of gardening shears .
#Text=The old foliage will likely not look as pretty as new foliage in the height of summer .
#Text=Trim the dead branches after the new growth comes in .
#Text=Alternatively , you can wait until the new growth comes in to cut off the old fronds .
#Text=It 's best to do this early in the season .
#Text=Shear off the dead fronds near the crown to make your plant healthier and prettier .
#Text=You can also cut out any older fronds that are n't dead yet but look a little bedraggled .
#Text=Cut the outer edges of the fronds to create a desired shape .
#Text=If you do n't like the way your fern is shaped , simply trim the outer edges until it 's to your liking .
#Text=Use sharp scissors or kitchen shears to do the trimming .
#Text=It 's best to only trim the outer edges after you 've removed yellowing or dead fronds .
#Text=Keep in mind that the tips turn brown if you clip off the edges .
#Text=Trim a transplanted fern by half to help it thrive .
#Text=When you move a fern , it may need some help getting settled in its new location .
#Text=Cut back all the fronds by half , reducing the water your fern needs to support itself .
#Text=This technique lets the plant focus more attention on getting its roots settled .
#Text=Do n't worry .
#Text=Once the plant is settled , it will grow back .
#Text=Avoid pruning right before winter .
#Text=It can be tempting to cut off dead or dying fronds at the beginning of winter .
#Text=However , those fronds help protect the root crown throughout the winter .
#Text=In other words , leaving the old fronds in place can help your fern survive through the cold of winter and return in the spring .
#Text=Trimming Indoor Ferns
#Text=Cut off dead fronds as they appear .
#Text=Use a sharp pair of scissors to cut the fronds .
#Text=Dead fronds will be brown or black .
#Text=Cut them near the base of the frond , just above the joint .
#Text=You can use a sharp pair of scissors or a small pair of garden shears .
#Text=Remove any fronds infected with scales .
#Text=Scales are tiny insects that attack your plants .
#Text=They are small , reddish brown , and flat .
#Text=When scales attack the plant , the leaves will likely turn yellow and may weaken .
#Text=Look for scales on the underside of leaves along the vein or on the stems .
#Text=Scales can spread , so remove any fronds you see with shears or scissors .
#Text=If you have a bad infestation , you may need to throw out the houseplant so the scales do n't spread to other houseplants .
#Text=Outdoor ferns also get scales , but you should try controlling them with oil-based spray pesticides instead of pruning .
#Text=Chop the root runners that hang over the side of the pot .
#Text=Some ferns will get " runners , " sort of like a strawberry plant , except these are part of the plant 's root system .
#Text=These will be brown and woody .
#Text=Chop them near the soil in the pot with shears or scissors to increase the health of your plant .
#Text=These runners are draining energy from your plant .
#Text=By cutting them , you 're letting your plant focus on other vital areas .
#Text=Cut back to the base if desired .
#Text=If you are not liking the look of your plant at all , you can cut it down to just above the crown , much as you do with an outdoor fern .
#Text=Use sharp , clean scissors to cut off the fronds .
#Text=The fern will grow back from the crown , if you let it remain .
#Text=Things
#Text=You 'll Need
#Text=Shears
#Text=Sharp scissors , optional
#Text=Gloves , optional
#Text=Quick Summary
